description.narrative:
ICTJ (International Center for Transitional Justice) i Colombia har ansökt hos Sida om finansiering av 12 miljoner kronor för att genomföra "Landprogram Colombia” under perioden juni 2018 - mars 2022. Insatsen syftar till att stärka övergångsrättsliga processer i Colombia på ett sätt som främjar alla aktörers ansvar för den interna väpnade konflikten och uppfyllandet av brottsoffers rättigheter genom att 1) tillhandahålla jämförande internationell erfarenhet och tekniskt bistånd för att starta och genomföra övergångsrättsliga mekanismer och, genom att 2) stärka civilsamhällets och offrens organisationer för att öka deras deltagande i processen för övergångsrättvisa.
Insatsens totala budget är 52,26 miljoner kronor (6,2 miljoner USD) varav Sida kommer att finansiera 12 miljoner kronor (1,4 miljoner USD) och resterande 40,26 miljoner kronor (4,8 miljoner USD) är bidrag från andra givare (Norge, Nederländerna, Luxemburg). Cirka 5,5 miljoner kronor (646 000 USD) av budgeten kommer att vidareförmedlas från ICTJ till lokala organisationer i Colombia.

ICTJ (International Center for Transitional Justice) in Colombia has applied to Sida for funding of 12 million SEK to carry out the "Colombia Country Programme” during the period June 2018 - March 2022. The intervention aims at strengthening transitional justice processes in Colombia in a way that advances accountability of all actors to the internal armed conflict and the fulfilment of victims’ rights by 1) providing comparative international experience and technical assistance for the start-up and implementation of the transitional justice mechanisms; 2) strengthen the capacity of civil society and victims’ organizations in order to enhance their participation in the transitional justice process.
The intervention’s total budget is 52.26 million SEK (6.2 million USD) out of which Sida will fund 12 million SEK (1.4 million USD) and the remaining 40.26 million SEK (4.8 million USD) is contributed by other donors (Norway, Netherlands, Luxembourg). Approximately 5.5 million SEK (646,000 USD) of the intervention´s budget will be forwarded from ICTJ to local organizations in Colombia.

The program's overall objective is that transitional justice processes in Colombia are implemented in a way that advances accountability of all actors to the internal armed conflict and the fulfillment of victims' rights. In order to achieve this goal, ICTJ-Colombia will: (i) strengthen different social sectors and institutions, at the national and regional levels, by providing information, rigorous analysis and technical assistance to enable full and effective participation with feasible proposals for the implementation of the mechanisms in the Comprehensive System of Transitional Justice*; and (ii) provide comparative international experience, feasible proposals and technical assistance for the start-up and implementation of these mechanisms. * Chapter 5 of the Peace Accords between the Government of Colombia and the FARC designed a “Comprehensive System for Truth, Justice, Reparation and Non-repetition” which comprises the creation of a Special Jurisdiction for Peace (SJP), a Truth Commission (TC) and a Search Unit for the Missing Persons.

description.narrative: During the program’s second year, ICTJ continued offering technical assistance to the three institutions of the Comprehensive System of Transitional Justice, supporting civil society organizations (CSO) to meaningfully participate in the System and fostering cooperation of ex-combatants in transitional justice processes. Through this contribution, Sweden provides unearmarked support to ICTJ’s Colombia country program, most significant results are presented below. Outcome 1: The Special Jurisdiction for Peace (SJP) incorporates international and national standards and best practices into its operational design and implementation to guarantee victims' right to justice ICTJ is recognized among SJP magistrates and top management as a trustworthy, independent partner that provides expert advice and facilitates complex organizational processes. Such position allowed ICTJ to assist the SJP in the formulation of its special sanctions, conditionality and victims’ participation regimes, encouraging compliance with international standards and best practices. These regulations are central to an adequate development of transitional justice processes and have the potential to increase legitimacy and trust in the SJP. Technical assistance was also offered to the SJP to identify operational bottlenecks and enhance its performance, leading to recommendations for improved internal regulations, communications and international cooperation strategies. As per SJP request, ICTJ conducted training sessions on restorative justice and mediation with international experts, developed workshops with prosecutors and investigators on international criminal justice and facilitated working groups with different areas of the organization. Additional training strategies were developed with journalists, to promote a better understanding and communication about the SJP, and FARC defense teams, to provide tools that ensure a suitable representation of former combatants in judicial processes. To foster participation of civil society in transitional justice, ICTJ developed a methodology for preparing high quality reports to the SJP and provided technical and financial support to six organizations in this process. Reports presented by these CSOs cover a wide range of armed conflict dynamics previously lacking proper documentation, including violence against children, LGBTI people, teachers’ unions and the Communist Party. Complementarily, ICTJ is assisting the SJP to analyze the high volume of information contained in over 200 reports submitted by CSO thus far and address their demands, promoting a responsive and accountable approach to civic participation in the Jurisdiction. Outcome 2: Truth-seeking mechanisms in Colombia adopt an operational design and are implemented in accordance with national and international best practices, to guarantee effective realization of victims of their mandate and the participation of victims. ICTJ has stablished a strategic dialogue with the Truth Commission (TC) that allowed it to facilitate internal coordination processes, influence key decisions and serve as a bridge with other stakeholders. For example, ICTJ held a three-day conference where challenges facing the Colombia TC were discussed in light of international experiences, addressing issues as the handling of sensitive information, participation of public security forces and the drafting of recommendations for non-recurrence in the Commission’s final report. At the request of the TC, ICTJ supported an innovative dialogue among former armed actors (Army, paramilitaries and guerrillas) to reflect on their perspectives around the conflict, acknowledge responsibility and promote reconciliation. As unexpected results of these initiative, joint declarations were made by participants, working groups with ex-combatants were formalized and the TC adopted the methodology developed jointly with ICTJ to promote a similar dialogue in the Montes de María Region. In addition, ICTJ supported separate processes of former paramilitary commanders and FARC members for preparing reports to the TC on their roles and responsibilities in the armed conflict. Twelve organizations, organized in consortiums, received ICTJ’s technical and financial support to produce reports on human rights violations and violence in various conflict-affected regions, to be presented to the TC. Also, ICTJ facilitated the reactivation of the Roundtable for Truth, a network of CSO fostering truth-seeking and accompanying the work of the TC. Although ICTJ’s work with the Unit for the Search of Missing Persons (UBPD) continued to be rather limited, support was given offered for the formulation of its differential approaches (age, ethnicity and disabilities). Outcome 3: Different society and institutional actors engage in and take ownership of the goals and achievements of the mechanisms of the Comprehensive System and the Peace Agreement This outcome was reformulated in ICTJ’s 2019-2020 annual work plan, due to previous difficulties of ICTJ to work with collective reparation and reconciliation -previous outcomes 3 and 4-, resulting from lack of Government’s political will. These conditions persist as it has not been possible for ICTJ to establish strong working relations with the Victim’s Unit or other national institutions to make progress on reparation issues. In promoting the engagement of other stakeholders in the transitional justice system, ICTJ provided technical assistance for the implementation of the Special Investigation Unit (SIU) of the Attorney General’s Office, created in the Peace Agreement to dismantle criminal organizations, including those responsible for attacks against human rights defenders, social or political leaders and demobilized FARC members. Likewise, ICTJ developed a variety of communication products to inform the public on the transitional justice system and supported alternative media outlets to create the website “Periodismo de Verdad”, which covers the work of the TC and the UBPD to improve understanding of the system. Finally, a collective memory construction initiative was promoted in Serranía del Perijá, a critically conflict-affected region. This exercise allowed communities of 15 municipalities and two departments to reflect on their experiences during the armed conflict and produce localized memory through various expressions, like murals, maps and theater plays.
